quizzes.title: Ancient Indian Knowledge
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of ancient Indian scriptures, philosophy, and wisdom

questions.question: Who wrote the Arthashastra?
questions.explanation: Arthashastra was written by Chanakya, also known as Kautilya, during the Mauryan period. It covers statecraft, economic policy, and military strategy.

questions.question: Which is the oldest Veda?
questions.explanation: The Rigveda is the oldest of the four Vedas, containing 1,028 hymns dedicated to various deities, composed around 1500-1200 BCE.

questions.question: The Bhagavad Gita is part of the Mahabharata.
questions.explanation: The Bhagavad Gita is a 700-verse Hindu scripture that is part of the epic Mahabharata, set as a conversation between Prince Arjuna and Lord Krishna.

questions.question: What does 'Tat Tvam Asi' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Tat Tvam Asi' is one of the Mahavakyas (great sayings) from the Chandogya Upanishad, expressing the unity of the individual soul with the universal consciousness.

questions.question: Which scripture says 'Truth is one; the wise call it by many names'?
questions.explanation: This profound verse (Rigveda 1.164.46) expresses the concept of universal truth being expressed through different paths and names.

questions.question: How many Upanishads are considered principal or major?
questions.explanation: There are 13 principal Upanishads, though over 200 Upanishads exist in total. These 13 are considered the most important philosophical texts.

questions.question: The Vedas were originally transmitted orally before being written down.
questions.explanation: The Vedas were preserved through oral tradition for thousands of years with remarkable accuracy before being written down in the medieval period.

questions.question: Which text is known as the 'Song of God'?
questions.explanation: Bhagavad Gita literally means 'Song of God' and represents Lord Krishna's teachings to Arjuna on dharma, karma, and moksha.

quizzes.title: Modern Indian Thinkers
quizzes.description: Explore the wisdom of modern Indian philosophers and leaders

questions.question: Who said 'Arise, awake, and stop not until the goal is reached'?
questions.explanation: This famous quote by Swami Vivekananda emphasizes determination, self-empowerment, and the relentless pursuit of one's goals.

questions.question: Rabindranath Tagore won the Nobel Prize for which work?
questions.explanation: Tagore was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913 for Gitanjali, a collection of devotional poems.

questions.question: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam was known as the 'Missile Man of India'.
questions.explanation: Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam earned this title for his work on the development of ballistic missile and launch vehicle technology in India.

questions.question: Which modern thinker introduced Vedanta philosophy to the Western world?
questions.explanation: Swami Vivekananda's speech at the Parliament of the World's Religions in Chicago (1893) introduced Vedanta and Yoga to the West.

questions.question: Who founded the Sabarmati Ashram?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi established the Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad in 1917, which became the center of India's freedom movement.

questions.question: Rabindranath Tagore composed both the Indian and Bangladeshi national anthems.
questions.explanation: Tagore composed 'Jana Gana Mana' (India's national anthem) and 'Amar Sonar Bangla' (Bangladesh's national anthem).

questions.question: What was Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's role in independent India?
questions.explanation: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee of the Indian Constitution and is known as the Father of the Indian Constitution.

quizzes.title: Indian Scientific Heritage
quizzes.description: Discover the contributions of ancient Indian scientists and mathematicians

questions.question: Who is credited with the concept of zero?
questions.explanation: Brahmagupta was the first to formulate rules for arithmetic involving zero and negative numbers in his work Brahmasphutasiddhanta (628 CE).

questions.question: Sushruta is known as the father of which medical field?
questions.explanation: Sushruta, author of the Sushruta Samhita, is considered the father of surgery for his pioneering work in plastic surgery and surgical techniques.

questions.question: Aryabhata proposed that the Earth rotates on its axis.
questions.explanation: Aryabhata (476-550 CE) was the first to propose that the Earth rotates on its axis daily, centuries before this was accepted in Europe.

questions.question: Who wrote the astronomical text 'Siddhanta Shiromani'?
questions.explanation: Bhaskara II (1114-1185 CE) wrote Siddhanta Shiromani, a comprehensive astronomical work covering mathematics, astronomy, and spherical trigonometry.

questions.question: The ancient Indian system of medicine is called:
questions.explanation: Ayurveda, meaning 'science of life', is an ancient Indian system of medicine dating back over 3,000 years, based on balancing bodily energies.

quizzes.title: Daily Knowledge Challenge
quizzes.description: Random questions from all categories - test your comprehensive knowledge

questions.question: What is the main theme of the Bhagavad Gita?
questions.explanation: The Bhagavad Gita primarily teaches about dharma (duty), karma (action), and the path to self-realization through righteous living.

questions.question: Which poet wrote 'Where the mind is without fear'?
questions.explanation: This famous line is from Tagore's poem in Gitanjali, expressing his vision for an independent and enlightened India.

questions.question: Charaka is known for contributions to ancient Indian surgery.
questions.explanation: Charaka is known for the Charaka Samhita, a foundational text of Ayurveda focusing on internal medicine. Sushruta is known for surgery.

questions.question: The number system we use today originated in:
questions.explanation: The decimal number system (including zero) and Arabic numerals originated in ancient India and were transmitted to the Arab world and then to Europe.

questions.question: Which Upanishad contains the teaching 'Tat Tvam Asi'?
questions.explanation: The Chandogya Upanishad contains this great saying (Mahavakya) taught by sage Uddalaka to his son Svetaketu.

quizzes.title: Yoga & Meditation Philosophy
quizzes.description: Deep dive into the philosophy and practice of ancient yoga traditions

questions.question: Who is considered the father of Yoga?
questions.explanation: Patanjali is credited with compiling the Yoga Sutras, the foundational text of classical yoga philosophy, around 400 CE.

questions.question: How many limbs (ashtanga) are there in Patanjali's Yoga?
questions.explanation: Patanjali's Ashtanga Yoga consists of 8 limbs: Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, and Samadhi.

questions.question: Pranayama refers to physical postures in yoga.
questions.explanation: Pranayama refers to breath control techniques. Physical postures are called Asanas.

questions.question: What does 'Samadhi' mean in yoga philosophy?
questions.explanation: Samadhi is the eighth and final limb of yoga, representing complete meditative absorption and union with the divine.

questions.question: Which text is known as the encyclopedia of yoga?
questions.explanation: The Hatha Yoga Pradipika is a comprehensive manual on Hatha Yoga, covering asanas, pranayama, bandhas, and mudras.

questions.question: The word 'Yoga' comes from the Sanskrit root 'Yuj' meaning to unite or join.
questions.explanation: Yoga derives from 'Yuj', symbolizing the union of individual consciousness with universal consciousness.

questions.question: What are the Yamas in Patanjali's Yoga Sutras?
questions.explanation: Yamas are the first limb of yoga, consisting of five ethical restraints: Ahimsa, Satya, Asteya, Brahmacharya, and Aparigraha.

questions.question: Which chakra is located at the crown of the head?
questions.explanation: Sahasrara (Crown Chakra) is the seventh primary chakra, associated with spiritual connection and enlightenment.

quizzes.title: Indian Architecture & Arts
quizzes.description: Explore India's rich architectural heritage and classical arts

questions.question: Which monument is known as the 'Symbol of Love'?
questions.explanation: The Taj Mahal in Agra, built by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal, is celebrated as a symbol of eternal love.

questions.question: The Sun Temple of Konark is dedicated to which deity?
questions.explanation: The 13th-century Konark Sun Temple in Odisha is dedicated to Surya, the Sun God, and is designed as a giant chariot.

questions.question: The Ajanta Caves contain Buddhist paintings and sculptures.
questions.explanation: The Ajanta Caves in Maharashtra feature ancient Buddhist cave paintings and rock-cut sculptures dating from the 2nd century BCE.

questions.question: How many classical dance forms are recognized in India?
questions.explanation: India recognizes 8 classical dance forms: Bharatanatyam, Kathak, Kathakali, Kuchipudi, Manipuri, Mohiniyattam, Odissi, and Sattriya.

questions.question: The Natya Shastra, ancient text on performing arts, was written by:
questions.explanation: Bharata Muni's Natya Shastra (200 BCE - 200 CE) is the foundational treatise on theater, dance, and music in India.

questions.question: The Ellora Caves feature only Hindu temples.
questions.explanation: The Ellora Caves in Maharashtra contain Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain monuments, showcasing religious harmony.

questions.question: Which city is known as the 'Pink City' of India?
questions.explanation: Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan, is called the Pink City due to the distinctive pink-colored buildings in its old town.

questions.question: The Sanchi Stupa was built during which empire?
questions.explanation: Emperor Ashoka commissioned the Great Stupa at Sanchi in the 3rd century BCE as a Buddhist monument.

quizzes.title: Ancient Indian Mathematics
quizzes.description: Discover India's groundbreaking contributions to mathematics

questions.question: Who first used the concept of zero as a number?
questions.explanation: Brahmagupta (628 CE) was the first mathematician to treat zero as a number and formulate rules for arithmetic operations involving zero.

questions.question: The decimal place-value system originated in:
questions.explanation: The decimal place-value system and modern numerals (0-9) were developed in ancient India and later transmitted to the Arab world.

questions.question: Aryabhata calculated the value of Pi (π) accurately to four decimal places.
questions.explanation: Aryabhata calculated π as approximately 3.1416, which is accurate to four decimal places, in the 5th century CE.

questions.question: The Sulba Sutras contain knowledge of which mathematical concept?
questions.explanation: The Sulba Sutras (800-500 BCE) contain geometric principles including the Pythagorean theorem, predating Pythagoras.

questions.question: Bhaskara II's work 'Lilavati' deals with:
questions.explanation: Lilavati is a mathematical treatise covering arithmetic, algebra, and geometry, written in elegant Sanskrit verse.

questions.question: The concept of infinity was discussed in ancient Indian mathematics.
questions.explanation: Ancient Indian mathematicians like Jaina mathematicians classified infinities and worked with the concept of infinitesimals.

questions.question: Who wrote the 'Aryabhatiya'?
questions.explanation: Aryabhata authored the Aryabhatiya in 499 CE, a mathematical and astronomical treatise covering algebra, trigonometry, and astronomy.

questions.question: The Kerala School of Astronomy developed early concepts of:
questions.explanation: Madhava of Sangamagrama and the Kerala School developed infinite series and calculus concepts in the 14th-16th centuries.

quizzes.title: Indian Languages & Literature
quizzes.description: Explore the linguistic diversity and literary heritage of India

questions.question: How many languages are officially recognized by the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Eighth Schedule of the Indian Constitution recognizes 22 scheduled languages including Hindi, Bengali, Tamil, Telugu, and others.

questions.question: Which is the oldest written language still in use?
questions.explanation: Tamil is one of the oldest living languages with a literary tradition dating back over 2,000 years.

questions.question: Sanskrit is the mother of all Indo-European languages.
questions.explanation: Sanskrit is not the mother but a sister language to other Indo-European languages, all descended from Proto-Indo-European.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Bard of Bengal'?
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore is celebrated as the Bard of Bengal for his profound contributions to Bengali literature and music.

questions.question: The epic Ramayana was written by:
questions.explanation: Sage Valmiki composed the original Sanskrit Ramayana, one of India's greatest epic poems.

questions.question: The Devanagari script is used only for Hindi.
questions.explanation: Devanagari is used for multiple languages including Hindi, Sanskrit, Marathi, Nepali, and others.

questions.question: Which language is known as the 'Italian of the East'?
questions.explanation: Telugu is called the 'Italian of the East' because every word ends with a vowel sound, similar to Italian.

questions.question: The Sangam literature is associated with which language?
questions.explanation: Sangam literature is a collection of ancient Tamil texts dating from 300 BCE to 300 CE.

quizzes.title: Indian Freedom Movement
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of India's struggle for independence

questions.question: When did the Jallianwala Bagh massacre take place?
questions.explanation: The Jallianwala Bagh massacre occurred on April 13, 1919, in Amritsar, when British troops fired on peaceful protesters.

questions.question: Who gave the slogan 'Give me blood, and I will give you freedom'?
questions.explanation: Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose used this rallying cry to inspire Indians to join the Indian National Army.

questions.question: The Quit India Movement was launched in 1942.
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi launched the Quit India Movement on August 8, 1942, demanding an end to British rule.

questions.question: Who was the first woman president of the Indian National Congress?
questions.explanation: Annie Besant was elected as the first woman president of the Indian National Congress in 1917.

questions.question: The Salt March (Dandi March) was undertaken in which year?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi led the Salt March from March 12 to April 6, 1930, to protest the British salt monopoly.

questions.question: Bhagat Singh was executed at the age of 23.
questions.explanation: Revolutionary freedom fighter Bhagat Singh was hanged on March 23, 1931, at the age of 23.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Vande Mataram'?
questions.explanation: Bankim Chandra Chatterjee composed 'Vande Mataram' in his novel Anandamath (1882), which became a rallying cry for independence.

questions.question: The Indian National Congress was founded in which year?
questions.explanation: The Indian National Congress was established in 1885 by Allan Octavian Hume, Dadabhai Naoroji, and Dinshaw Wacha.
